title: 111_s3957
content: The "Graduate Medical Education Reform Act of 2010" includes provisions for Medicare indirect medical education performance adjustment, primary care training bonus, payments for graduate medical education to hospitals, transparency in graduate medical education, establishment of a trust fund, and financing the trust fund through fees on health plans. Section 1886(d)(5)(B) of the Social Security Act is amended to include an adjustment for hospital payments based on performance on health care workforce priorities specified by the Secretary, including training in primary care. The text specifies measures for health care workforce priorities, including primary care training, various settings, patient care coordination, cost considerations, interprofessional teams, system error identification, and health information technology use. The Secretary shall identify measures developed through a consensus-based process by accredited organizations for use in healthcare workforce priorities. A proposed set of measures will be published for public comment by January 1, 2013, with a final set to be specified by June 30, 2013. The Secretary will determine adjustments to hospital payments under this clause, not exceeding 3 percent of the total amount. The total payments to hospitals must remain budget neutral, ensuring no increase in total payments compared to if the clause had not been enacted. Primary care is defined as family medicine and general practice. The term "primary care" includes family medicine, general internal medicine, general pediatrics, preventive medicine, obstetrics and gynecology, and psychiatry. Bonus payments are provided to hospitals for training in primary care during a 12-month applicable period starting on July 1 each year. The bonus payment is equal to 1 percent of payments for indirect medical education costs if at least 33 percent of full-time equivalent residents are enrolled in primary care during the applicable period. Residents enrolled in the hospital's medical residency training programs in primary care are eligible for bonus payments from the Medical Education Trust Fund. The total payments to eligible hospitals for primary care training during an applicable period are limited to the funds appropriated to the Trust Fund for that fiscal year. SEC. 3. Payments for graduate medical education to hospitals not otherwise eligible under the Medicare program are addressed in Title XVIII of the Social Security Act. This section pertains to graduate medical education payments for hospitals not otherwise eligible. The Secretary will establish a program for payments to eligible hospitals for medical residency training programs. Payments will be made from the Medical Education Trust Fund and are subject to certain requirements. Total payments in a period cannot exceed the funds appropriated to the Trust. The program establishes payments to eligible hospitals for medical residency training programs from the Medical Education Trust Fund. Eligible hospitals include children's hospitals, freestanding psychiatric hospitals with specific criteria, and hospitals with a high annual birth rate and low Medicare discharges. The program establishes payments to eligible hospitals for medical residency training programs from the Medical Education Trust Fund. Eligible hospitals include children's hospitals, freestanding psychiatric hospitals with specific criteria, and hospitals with a high annual birth rate and low Medicare discharges. Annual discharges from the hospital are Medicare discharges of individuals entitled to benefits under part A, not enrolled in certain Medicare plans, with their own Medicare provider number, and an accredited residency program. The term 'applicable period' is defined in section 1886(d)(5)(B)(xii)(VII), and the Secretary will promulgate regulations for implementation. SEC. 4. INCREASING GRADUATE MEDICAL EDUCATION TRANSPARENCY. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit an annual report to Congress and the National Health Care Workforce Commission on graduate medical education payments hospitals receive under Medicare. The report includes details on direct and indirect education payments, the number of residents counted for payments, and any residents not counted for payments. The annual report to Congress and the National Health Care Workforce Commission includes details on graduate medical education payments hospitals receive under Medicare. This includes the number of residents counted for payments, residents not counted, and the percentage of payments made to hospitals in relation to total costs incurred for education. SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF TRUST FUND. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to add a new section: "SEC. 9512. MEDICAL EDUCATION TRUST FUND." The Medical Education Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by appropriations and fees on health insurance and self-insured plans. No transfers are allowed after expenditures not permitted under this section. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is designated as a trustee of the Trust Fund, with amounts available for expenditures without further appropriation. Net revenues are defined as fees received in the Treasury minus the decrease in taxes resulting from those fees. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is designated as a trustee of the Trust Fund, with net revenues defined as fees received in the Treasury minus the decrease in taxes resulting from those fees. The table of sections for subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new item. SEC. 6. PARTIAL FINANCING FOR TRUST FUND FROM FEES ON INSURED AND SELF-INSURED HEALTH PLANS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase fees on health plans for partial financing of the Trust Fund.
